awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  X-ray Diffraction in High Magnetic Fields: A proof of concept diffractometer for the Florida Split Coil 25T Magnet
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to Florida State University is to develop a workable 'proof of concept' X-ray diffractometer to take advantage of the new 25T split-coil magnet at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory (NHMFL).  X-ray diffraction and scattering techniques in high magnetic fields will be used to investigate spin-lattice coupling, magnetostriction, and orbital ordering effects in strongly correlated materials.  This 'proof of concept' system will address the effects of large fringe fields on detectors, X-ray sources, and mechanical components. Potential materials to be investigated will include, multiferroic, magnetoelectric, and, thermomagnetic materials, spin-cross-over systems, and geometrically frustrated magnetic systems.

The 'proof of concept' X-ray diffractometer will be the first available at steady state magnetic fields above 13T.  It will provide a unique capability to probe the magnetic responses in materials and is expected to lead to new science.  The new instrument will pave the way for a next generation diffraction system with enhanced capabilities open to the scientific community through the NHMFL.

A magnetic field is an excellent probe for the nature of the electrons that are responsible for bonding the atoms in a material. Additionally, atoms with electrons in an unfilled shell carry a magnetic moment that interacts with an external magnetic. Such an interaction produces  displacements of atoms in a material, changes that affect the crystallographic symmetry and the unit cell parameters a a crystalline material. These properties that can be measured using an X-ray diffractometer.

A small X-ray diffractometer has been developed at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory. It brings experimental diffraction capabilities to the 25 Tesla Florida Split Coil Magnet, the strongest split coil magnet in the world (Figure 1). Low temperature control in the range of 15 to 295 K was implemented using a helium cryostat.  The magnet, at athe highest field of 25 T, consumes about 28 MW of electrical power, requiring a cooling water flow of 10m3/min at 17 bar of pressure, producing vibrations of the whole magnet. Magnetic fringe fields are present that, at a distance of 6 meters from the magnet, are about twenty times stronger than the earth magnetic field (1mT). These large fringe fields will affect electronic components in the X-ray source and X-ray detectors, requiring active or passive magnetic shielding  to ensure proper functioning of all the system components. 

   The magnet vibrations were mitigated by mechanically decoupling the X-ray source and the sample from the magnet itself.  X-ray sources and detectors susceptible to magnetic fields should not be exposed magnetic fields larger than 1mT, about 20 times the strength of the earth magnetic field. The X-ray source was placed at the 3mT line, about 3.5 m away from the sample space, and an active shielding system for the vertical field component was added: a Helmholtz coil system, reducing the vertical component of the external magnetic field to below a tenth of 1 mT. To bring the X-rays to the sample, a 2 m long evacuated beam tunnel with X-ray transparent beryllium windows was installed, with the tunnel also providing radiation protection. At the magnet side of the beam tunnel, a simple slit system is used to adjust the primary beam size and the beam divergence. Figure 2 shows the source side setup of the X-ray diffractometer installed on tables positioned around the split coil magnet. 

  Detectors should be placed close to the magnet exit port, but there, the magnetic fringe fields are about 0.2T (about 4000 times the strength of the earth magnetic field).  Figure 3 shows the exit port of the magnet with an X-ray transparent window where detectors will be placed.  Detectors that tolerate such magnetic fields include photographic films, image plates, and some semiconductor detectors, whereas traditional scintillation counters are not suitable. Image plates are inexpensive and can cover a large 2-dimensional area, a desired geometry for recording diffracted intensities. We use a 20 cm by 40 cm FujiFilmimage plate (with pixel size of 50 micrometer) mounted on a frame that is directly attached to the exit port of the magnet and covers an angle range of -3° to +27° or +11° ­to +42°. A semiconductor based detector with direct readout and energy discrimination may be placed close to the exit ports of the magnet, but modifications are needed to eliminate electronic components susceptible to magnetic fields. One of the semiconductor detectors tested was a modified hybrid pixel array photon counting detector PILATUS 100K-S with a detection area of 83.8 x 33.5 mm2.
